term.definition: An order designed to help limit loss and lock in profit by "bracketing" an order with two opposite-side orders.

Involves a combination of buying and selling multiple options to create a spread with three strike prices. - Example: Buy one call option at a lower strike price, sell two call options at a middle strike price, and buy one call option at a higher strike price.

Involves buying and selling options of the same type and strike price but with different expiration dates. - Example: Buy a call option with a later expiration date and sell a call option with an earlier expiration date.
Gives the holder the right to buy the underlying asset.
Involves holding a long position in an underlying asset and selling a call option on that asset. - Example: Own the underlying stock and sell a call option on the same stock.

Involves buying and selling options of the same type but with different strike prices and expiration dates. - Example: Buy a call option with a higher strike price and later expiration date, and sell a call option with a lower strike price and earlier expiration date.
The process of completing an order. It can involve various states such as NEW, ACCEPTED, WORKING, FILLED, CANCELED and REJECTED.

A futures contract is a standardized agreement to buy or sell an asset at a predetermined price at a specified time in the future. Futures contracts can be used for hedging or speculative purposes. They are traded on exchanges and are highly liquid

Futures options are options on futures contracts. They give the holder the right, but not the obligation, to enter into a futures contract at a specified price before the option expires. This combines the features of both futures and options, providing flexibility and leverage.
A strategy where the execution of one order triggers another order.

Involves selling a straddle and buying a strangle. - Example: Sell a call and a put option at the same strike price, and buy a call option at a higher strike price and a put option at a lower strike price.

Involves selling a call and a put option at one strike price and buying a call and a put option at different strike prices. - Example: Sell a call and a put option at middle strike prices, buy a call option at a higher strike price, and buy a put option at a lower strike price.
An order to buy or sell once the market reaches a specified price
An order instantly executed against a price provided by the broker. It is executed at the current market price.
A pair of orders where the execution of one order cancels the other.
An option is a financial derivative that gives the buyer the right, but not the obligation, to buy or sell an underlying asset at a specified price before or at a certain date.
An instruction sent to open or close a transaction if the conditions specified by a user are satisfied. Orders can be market orders or pending orders (limit and stop orders).
A combination of single orders linked by particular rules to achieve a specific result. Examples include OCO (One Cancels the Other) and IF-THEN strategies.

Involves holding a long position in an underlying asset and buying a put option to protect against a decline in the asset's price. - Example: Own the underlying stock and buy a put option on the same stock.
Gives the holder the right to sell the underlying asset.
An order to buy or sell at a certain price in the direction of the implied market movement. It becomes a market order once the stop price is reached.
Involves buying both a call and a put option with the same strike price and expiration date. - Example: Buy a call and a put option at the same strike price.

Involves buying both a call and a put option with different strike prices but the same expiration date. - Example: Buy a call option with a higher strike price and a put option with a lower strike price.
Indicates how long an order will remain active before it expires. Examples include GTC (Good Till Canceled), DAY, and GTD (Good Till Date).
Order that moves with the market price to lock in profits while limiting losses.

Involves buying and selling options of the same type (calls or puts) with different strike prices but the same expiration date. - Example: Buy a call option with a lower strike price and sell a call option with a higher strike price.
